title: Erdős Problem #275: Covering Congruences
description: If r congruences {aᵢ (mod nᵢ)} cover 2^r consecutive integers, they cover all integers. This bound is tight: {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i)} shows 2^r-1 doesn't suffice.

overview.historicalContext: This problem concerns 'covering systems' - finite collections of congruence classes that cover all integers. Erdős pioneered the study of such systems. The question asks: how many consecutive integers must r congruence classes cover to guarantee they cover all integers? The answer is exactly 2^r, proved independently by Selfridge and by Crittenden-Vanden Eynden in 1970.
overview.problemStatement:
If a finite system of r congruences {aᵢ (mod nᵢ) : 1 ≤ i ≤ r} covers 2^r consecutive integers, then it covers all integers.

**This bound is tight:** The system {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i) : 1 ≤ i ≤ r} covers exactly the integers NOT divisible by 2^r, showing that 2^r - 1 consecutive integers don't suffice.
overview.proofStrategy:
The formalization defines:
1. Congruence classes as sets of integers
2. Covering systems as finite collections of such classes
3. The main theorem: 2^r consecutive integers suffice
4. The optimal example showing tightness

The proof (axiomatized) uses induction on the structure of moduli mod 2.
keyInsights: 2^r consecutive integers suffice for r congruences to cover all ℤ
The bound is tight: {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i)} shows 2^r-1 doesn't work
Binary representation intuition: all r-bit patterns appear in 2^r consecutive integers
Independently proved by Selfridge and Crittenden-Vanden Eynden (1970)
Related to covering systems - a fundamental topic in combinatorial number theory

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #275 is SOLVED. If r congruence classes cover 2^r consecutive integers, they cover all integers. The bound 2^r is optimal, as shown by the example {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i) : 1 ≤ i ≤ r} which needs exactly 2^r consecutive integers.
conclusion.implications: This result characterizes the threshold for finite covering by congruence classes. It shows that the exponential bound 2^r, rather than any polynomial, is the critical threshold.
openQuestions: Does there exist a covering system with all distinct odd moduli? (Erdős's $1000 problem)
What are the minimal covering systems for small r?
How do these results extend to other algebraic structures?
